key_terms.term_description: Rate on Line (ROL) percentages for each layer (18%, 12%, 8%)
key_terms.rationale: The proposed ROLs are at the high end or above current market benchmarks per the market conditions report (16-19% for lower, 10-13% for middle, 7-9% for upper layers).

key_terms.term_description: Exclusion for losses from named storms that have entered the Gulf of Mexico prior to attachment
key_terms.rationale: This is a new, restrictive exclusion that significantly reduces coverage for a key exposure area given our 30% portfolio concentration in the Southeast region.

key_terms.term_description: Two free reinstatements for Layer 1, one reinstatement at 100% for Layer 2, one at 125% for Layer 3
key_terms.rationale: The reinstatement terms for Layer 2 and especially Layer 3 (at 125%) are less favorable than market standards, which typically offer one reinstatement at 100% for middle and upper layers.
While described as 'standard' by the reinsurer, this creates a relatively short window for reporting losses that occurred during the treaty period but may take longer to develop or be reported.

key_terms.term_description: Requirement not to increase exposure in high-risk zones by more than 15% without prior notification
key_terms.rationale: This restricts business flexibility and growth opportunities in potentially profitable regions without reinsurer approval.

market_comparison.layer1_assessment: Above market - 18% ROL vs. market benchmark of 16-19% (high end)
market_comparison.layer2_assessment: Above market - 12% ROL vs. market benchmark of 10-13% (mid-range)
market_comparison.layer3_assessment: Above market - 8% ROL vs. market benchmark of 7-9% (mid-range)

pros: Slightly lower ROL in Layer 2 (10% vs 12%)
cons: Reduced upper layer coverage ($20M vs $25M in Layer 3)

pros: Higher attachment point reduces frequency of Layer 1 claims
cons: Reduced coverage in Layer 1 due to higher attachment

pros: Reduced reinstatement cost in Layer 2 (75% vs 100%)
Increased total coverage due to more reinstatements
cons: Reduced upper layer limit ($20M vs $25M in Layer 3)

premium_rates.target: Layer 1: 16% ROL, Layer 2: 10% ROL, Layer 3: 7% ROL
premium_rates.minimum: Layer 1: 17% ROL, Layer 2: 11% ROL, Layer 3: 7.5% ROL

gulf_exclusion.target: Complete removal of the Gulf of Mexico named storm exclusion
gulf_exclusion.minimum: Modified exclusion that only applies to named storms of Category 3 or higher that have entered the Gulf within 72 hours of attachment

reinstatement_provisions.target: Layer 1: Two free reinstatements, Layer 2: One free reinstatement, Layer 3: One reinstatement at 100%
reinstatement_provisions.minimum: Layer 1: Two free reinstatements, Layer 2: One reinstatement at 75%, Layer 3: One reinstatement at 100%

portfolio_protection.target: Increase threshold to 25% exposure growth in high-risk zones before notification
portfolio_protection.minimum: Increase threshold to 20% exposure growth in high-risk zones before notification

concessions.concession_item: Accept increased minimum premium from 85% to 90% of annual premium
concessions.rationale: This provides greater certainty to the reinsurer while having minimal impact if we maintain our current business volume.

concessions.concession_item: Accept more stringent claims notification period of 21 days instead of the offered 30 days
concessions.rationale: Our internal processes typically report claims within 14 days anyway, so this is not operationally burdensome while showing good faith.

concessions.concession_item: Accept quarterly exposure reporting requirement instead of the current unspecified frequency
concessions.rationale: We already maintain detailed catastrophe modeling, so providing regular reports demonstrates transparency and commitment to sound risk management.

key_points: Acknowledge the challenging market conditions while emphasizing our strong historical relationship
Address their concerns about Southeast exposure concentration with details on our risk mitigation strategies
Highlight our improved catastrophe modeling and risk management processes
Emphasize the need for more competitive pricing given our long-term partnership
Express willingness to work collaboratively on a mutually beneficial agreement

proposed_modifications.current_language: Layer 1: 18% Rate on Line (ROL), Layer 2: 12% ROL, Layer 3: 8% ROL
proposed_modifications.proposed_language: Layer 1: 16.5% Rate on Line (ROL), Layer 2: 11% ROL, Layer 3: 7.5% ROL
proposed_modifications.justification: Based on the market conditions report, these rates align more closely with current benchmarks while still acknowledging our loss history. Our 5-year average loss ratio remains favorable, and we've implemented enhanced risk management protocols to mitigate future losses.

proposed_modifications.current_language: This Treaty excludes: Losses from named storms that have entered the Gulf of Mexico prior to attachment
proposed_modifications.proposed_language: This Treaty excludes: Losses from named storms of Category 3 or higher that have entered the Gulf of Mexico within 96 hours prior to attachment
proposed_modifications.justification: The blanket Gulf exclusion is overly restrictive given our portfolio. This modification provides protection against imminent severe storms while maintaining coverage for our significant Southeast exposure. We've enhanced our catastrophe response protocols specifically for Gulf storms.

proposed_modifications.current_language: Layer 1: Two free reinstatements, Layer 2: One reinstatement at 100% of pro-rata premium, Layer 3: One reinstatement at 125% of pro-rata premium
proposed_modifications.proposed_language: Layer 1: Two free reinstatements, Layer 2: One reinstatement at 100% of pro-rata premium, Layer 3: One reinstatement at 100% of pro-rata premium
proposed_modifications.justification: The 125% reinstatement premium for Layer 3 exceeds market standards. Our historical data shows only two events in five years that would have triggered Layer 3, demonstrating the low frequency of such losses. A 100% reinstatement premium is fair and aligns with market practices.

proposed_modifications.current_language: The Reinsurer's liability shall terminate for all losses occurring prior to the expiration of this Treaty that are not reported to the Reinsurer within 36 months after the expiration of this Treaty.
proposed_modifications.proposed_language: The Reinsurer's liability shall terminate for all losses occurring prior to the expiration of this Treaty that are not reported to the Reinsurer within 48 months after the expiration of this Treaty.
proposed_modifications.justification: Property catastrophe claims occasionally develop beyond 36 months, particularly with complex commercial claims or when legal proceedings are involved. A 48-month reporting period provides reasonable protection for both parties while acknowledging the potential for delayed claim reporting in catastrophic events.
